thread.title: ILO welcomes G7 measures for sustainable global supply chains
thread.title_full: ILO welcomes G7 measures for sustainable global supply chains

author: Dan Alexe
title: ILO welcomes G7 measures for sustainable global supply chains
text:
9 shares What's This? G7 announced their commitments to fair trade and sustainable supply chains at the end of the two-days meeting in Berlin, which focused on Employment, Labour, Social Affairs, International Cooperation and Development.
On 13 October, the International Labour Organization (ILO) welcomed the announcement of the G7 (Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, UK and the US) to mobilize their joint efforts to boost “labour rights, decent working conditions and environmental protection in global supply chains.”
According to ILO, the ministers agreed on a series of measures, including the creation of a multi-donor Vision Zero Fund for action in producing countries. The fund will support social dialogue and the application ILO standards on occupational safety and health (OSH) and fundamental principles and rights at work in global supply chains.
“The Vision Zero Fund will help prevent and reduce the unacceptable number of workplace-related deaths, injuries and diseases. Gaining access to global supply chains can be an important part of strategies for poverty reduction. The Fund will help to make this route safer,” said ILO Director-General Guy Ryder, who was at the meeting. The final declaration of the G7 ministers states that the ILO will assume the lead role in the implementation of the Fund and the first activities are due to start in 2016.
The German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development, announced that Minister Gerd Müller, lobbied successfully to get the enforcement of global labour, social and environmental standards on theG7 agenda for the first time in history. The Minister said:
“There was some discussion, but in the end we were able to say with pride that, together with Germany’s Labour Minister, Andrea Nahles, and the Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (BMAS), we were able to win the backing of our G7 partners. At their summit in Elmau the G7 agreed on concrete steps for implementing labour, social and environmental standards in textile supply chains. Decent work and sustainable production are to become the global norm…These new initiatives…will establish an important connection between living conditions in developing countries and consumption patterns in rich industrialised countries.”
According to ILO figures, 2.3 million men and women die every year from work-related accidents and diseases.
